0064409422|5.0|It's been a long time since I read The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe as a child but, even now, I can remember the magic that book gave me. I've just re-read it as an adult and it's still a wonderful, spriritual experience - perhaps more so.<br />CS Lewis wrote these books with a very obvious allegory - obvious, perhaps, for everyone except the target audience! Some people will say, therefore, that these are Christian books - suitable only for Christians perhaps? But I strongly disagree. The tales provide strong moral guidelines (in The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, Edmund is led astray by the empty promises of the white witch and has to have his sin's redeemed by a sacrifice) but they can be read at many levels and one is just a pure fairy tale. It is really a tale of good versus evil.<br />In this book (which despite the re-numbering, I still consider to be the first book!), we are introduced to the four children - brothers and sisters - who's adventures we see. Like many children's authors, CS Lewis uses the concept of separation from the parents to provide a safe haven for imagination - in this case wartime evacuation leads to a very strange house with a wonderful old man who allows them - encourages them - to explore what truth is. In this case \\"truth\\" lies beyond a wardrobe in the magical land of Narnia. A land in the midst of a permanent winter caused by the magic of an evil queen. As the children explore this world, and meet it's good and bad inhabitants, they are each changed and grow with the experience.<br />The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a very accessible book open to young readers - in fact, it would be suitable for one of the first chapter books I feel. Yet it has enough depth that it can be read by older children again and again - much as I did as a child!

I'd thought), to social warnings like &quot;Red Telephone&quot; (the song quoted above) and &quot;Live and Let Live&quot; (&quot;Oh, the snot has caked against my pants...&quot;--which is really about violence against American Indians), to the uplifting, soul-stirring &quot;You Set the Scene&quot; (&quot;this is the time and life that I am living...&quot;).  Often this music has sweet melodies juxtaposed against piercing, even scathing lyrics, layered with a brass-and-violins orchestral arrangement.  But then, I've always liked the blending of classical stylings with rock music.  Highly, HIGHLY recommended!  Thanks, Ken, for putting this into my life and consciousness!

0887307280|5.0|I was referred to this book by someone who immersed himself in Michael Gerber's philosophy.  This person was able to create a successful and profitable business based on the concepts presented in this book.  <br />The philosophy is broken down in two main themes.  The first is that too many people work in their business, and not enough people work on their business.  The second is that most successful businesses, regardless of their size, operate in a franchise model.  This means the business can operate as a turn-key model, which would make it easy to sell or replicate anywhere.<br />Gerber opines that most small businesses in the US fail.  It is not because the people running them are stupid; they are not.  Many people allow too many assumptions to get in the way of running a business.  Contrary to a popular myth, most successful businesses are not run exclusively by entrepreneurs.  They are also not run exclusively by managers.  He walks the reader through the steps of maturity in the life of business, including the different types of people involved with operating the business.<br />This is a must read for small business owners and sales professionals.  There is a reason companies like McDonald's, Federal Express, Starbucks, etc. are so successful.

B0000AI44Q|5.0|At this point, Neil Young could've sat back and churned out a dozen catchy songs or made a shameless greatest hits record like most artists his age.  However, he has chosen to go in a completely new direction yet again.  Greendale is a concept album.  It is a musical stoytelling of characters which seem so real and texturous that they come alive in your imagination.  Greendale is also set to the jagged backing of the band Crazy Horse.  The record takes a couple listens to really grasp, and unfolds more with each listen.  Included in the package is a DVD of Neil perfoming the whole songlist solo, giving narrations and storytelling in between songs.  It is never possible to figure out what Neil will do next, and few artists still challenge us in that way.

0930289528|5.0|This story shows England in 1996 (it was the future in 1987, when this was writter) and how it has become a fascist and over-bearing society that is teeming w/ corruption, greed and misery. The whole of England is controlled by the leader who has equipped the streets and homes w/ microphones, video cameras in order to spy on its citizens. But all this is disrupted by a man who wears a mask w/ a large smile (see cover). Gradually throghout the story we see his origin (he was put in a concentration camp w/ the Gays, the Jews and the African-Americans and experimented upon). We also see the emergence of other chracters w/ a variety of motives and personalities who add to the story. It is close to the Watchmen story (also by Alan Moore) but it draws more closely to 1984 by Geroge Orwell. B00005JKCH|3.0|Watching \\"Spider-Man,\\" I was reminded of the first time I saw \\"Batman.\\" I walked away from that movie awed by the visuals, but completely unmoved by the characters (even Jack Nicholson's over-the-top performance was a caricature, not a character). But \\"Spider-Man\\" did something very unusual for films in this genre: it made me care for the people in it far more than I cared for its spectacle.<br />And, in reflection, that's a good thing, since the spectacle here isn't all that spectacular. More about that later - for now, let's just say that \\"Spider-Man\\" is perhaps the most emotionally involving comic-book movie ever made. <br />That is in no small part due to Tobey Maguire, who is absolutely perfect as the all-too-human Peter Parker, a nerdy young man who is bitten by a \\"super spider\\" and develops superhuman capabilities. At first, he simply tries to cash in on his newfound powers, as any teenager probably would, but he's reminded tragically that someone who has his capabilities should be using them to better the world, not to rule on \\"WWF Smackdown.\\"  <br />This is, of course, the essential \\"backstory\\" that all comic book characters have, and this one really clicks. Batman is a borderline personality, and Superman is too good for his own good; in \\"Spider-Man,\\" we have a pretty normal guy who's only abnormal in his capabilities, which makes him darned easy to relate to, and admire.<br />It's all about motivation when it comes to comic books. Batman is motivated by emotional pain, and Superman is motivated by his too-good-to-be-true nature; it's very difficult to see either character's life playing out much differently than they do. But Peter's destiny is chosen, not by his psychological problems or emotional programming, but by himself. He can be what he wants, and he wants to be a super-hero, but more importantly, he chooses to be a super-hero in a way that doesn't hurt his loved ones.<br />This means sacrificing things that most young men wouldn't be prepared to do without, most prominently the love of his life, Mary Jane (Kirsten Dunst). At first, Peter's too shy and insecure to do anything but pine away over her, but as his confidence grows, Mary Jane begins to see him in a different life, and eventually falls for him. But Peter chooses not to make himself avaiable to her for a simple reason: he's made all too aware that the only way to defeat Spider-Man is to hurt his loved ones. <br />The comparisons to other superheroes come up again. Batman is too screwed-up to have a normal relationship, and Superman is physically incapable of one without giving up his powers. But Peter would be perfectly capable of having having a normal love life, and probably would be a heck of a catch for any woman with half a brain, and chooses not to because it would endanger her.<br />There's real humanity and pathos in that decision, and Maguire's performance really brings that out.<br />There's also real humanity in the central villain, Norman Osborne (Willem Dafoe), a corporate magnate who inadvertently releases a lot more than his physical potential when he tests out his company's performance enhancing drug. His personality splits between the marginally likeable Osborne, and the Green Goblin, who's the kind of villain that likes to roll off long, evil laughs and lines like, \\"he must be instructed in pain and loss.\\" Osborne's son Harry (James Franco) is Parker's best friend, and even after Spider-Man finally defeats him, Osborne's dying wish is that his son never finds out about his secret supervillain side. Of course, Peter, being the honorable guy that he is, honors that dying wish, even when Harry threatens revenge against Spider-Man.<br />How long has it been since we saw a villain in one of these movies with real humanity? Only Lex Luthor, and perhaps Jim Carrey's Riddler, come close. All the rest, including Nicholson's Joker, are just cartoon characters - fun to watch, but ultimately empty and uninvolving.<br />This all makes for a good basic drama, built on nice dialogue and fine performances - a rarity in films of this sort, which almost invariably succeed as spectacle and fail miserably as drama. But \\"Spider-Man\\" has the opposite problem - it succeeds as drama but fails a spectacle.<br />The fight sequences play well, but whenever Spider-Man takes to the air, and the CGI effects cross the screen, it plays like a video game - flat, graceless, and obvious. Spider-Man looks no more real or graceful than Sonic the Hedgehog, and the effect is even more pronounced on a television screen. Many recent films, notably the latest Star Wars prequel, have shown that CGI can create animation that has real weight, realism and elegance. I don't know any other reason, save budgetary concerns, that would drive the filmmakers to settle for such obvious, silly effects here. <br />In the end, the effects don't ruin this film - the basic goodness of the story and the quality of its telling preclude that - but with better visuals, this would have been a total triumph. As it is, I'm sure that the immense success of this film will enable the producers to hire a more competent visual effects shop for the upcoming sequel.<br />And if that sequel is able to replica the human impact of \\"Spider-Man,\\" then that movie will truly be something to see.
B00006IU73|5.0|Prog Schmog. Can we please forego the obsession with musical pigeon-holing and simply acknowledge that Porcupine Tree is an unusual and exiting band - one that consistently defies musical genres from album to album and within each. One can find echoes of Pink Floyd, King Crimson, early CSN, NIN, The Doors, XTC... (Hence the lack of big label musical and visual recognition.) However, Steven Wilson describes these as \\"explorations\\" as opposed to imitation. I was fortunate enough to catch these guys in concert recently in Boston. Way beyond my expectations. Wandering and focused, thundering and dreamy. Wilson recalls when he was eight years old his parents simultaneously buying Dark side Of the Moon and Donna Summer's \\"Love To Love You Baby.\\" Prophetic. Never in my 30 plus years of musical exploration has an artist or band captured my attention so fully. Never has an album or CD received as much rotation in my collection as \\"In Absentia.\\" Buy this CD, even if you love Donna Summer.
B00007K02F|3.0|I love period films, epics, and film adaptations of classical literature.  I am not an expert, however.  I have seen this film quite a few times, but only in bits and pieces.  The dialog often drags, and it causes the viewer to grow impatient for some true &quot;meat&quot; to chew on.<br />I thought the beginning of the movie depicting Jane's childhood (I am not referencing it back to the text for authenticity, mind you) was quite good.  I watched this with interest.<br />I rather liked the young Adelle and the other characters at Thornfield.  However, the grave dissapointment came from Mr. Rochester.  While I am sure this gentleman may be a fine actor elsewhere, he was not suited for this role.  His coloring, his non-accent, his build, his mannerisms, all of these things gave him a large hurdle to overcome, and unfortunately he never did.  I found him to be very weird... not dark and peculiar like the true Mr. Rochester.  Because of this, I did not find myself longing for the ultimate union of the two characters in the end.<br />The black and white version was far better.
B00005JM09|4.0|T3 is by far the most unique of the series and of the sci-fi genre that I've seen in the past 5 years. It provides the series a slap in the face, if you will. One of the primary themes of the series has been \\"The future is not set. There is no fate but what we make for ourselves.\\" One of T3's most significant themes, quite contrary to this, is that some things are inevitable. Since the beginning, the Terminator series was man against machine, man wins. T3 turns the tide. The inevitability of the war and the machines rising crashes in on the audience. Now, part of the future will happen, no matter what is done to try to avoid it. This theme is frequently found in independent films that want to reveal a future that is as likely to happen as triumphant man, but do not cater to the popular vote or the highest dollar. This was totally unexpected, and is quite unnerving when you consider that in 100% of all box-office sci-fi hits, either 1) man triumphs, 2) man has the choice to control fate, or 3) that all of existance revolves around man. T3 took me by surprise, and I hope that it finds your guard down as well.

6305949980|5.0|Whether you are into Halloween, Christmas, or just good entertainment, this film is a must see.  The story follows the exploits of Halloweentown's most prominant citizen, Jack Skellington, as he searches within and without to become self actualized.  No longer satisfied with  the pedestrian hoopla that surrounds his holiday, Jack sets out to conquor Christmas and finds that the grass is not always greener on the other side.<br />Plot aside, this film with its obvious nod to the German Expressionist movement, is a feast for the eyes.  Its twisted perspective and dark, brooding sets appeal to my morose side, yet the overall atmosphere remains fun and humorous.  The production values are a veritible tour de force of the stop-motion animator's art and Danny Elfman's soundtrack is nothing less than a modern masterpiece!<br />You don't have to be a lonely, disenfranchised, &quot;goth&quot; teenager to appreciate the look of this film --it has something for everyone.  Some characters might be a tad too gruesome for impressionable little eyes, however.  I'd save this treat for the post-diaper set.<br />The Nightmare Before Christmas is destined to become a holiday classic in the tradition of the Great Pumpkin or Rudolph.
B000003TAB|5.0|This, in my own personal opinion, is the greatest Nirvana album ever released.  Though those new to Nirvana will want to start with &quot;Nevermind,&quot; &quot;Incesticide&quot; is still their finest masterpiece.  <br />It opens with &quot;Dive&quot;, a great opener with a bassline that pulls you in from the get-go.  It moves to &quot;Sliver,&quot; which I could fill the review about by itself; it's a childhood portrait that is both amusing and mildly chilling, with a great flow.<br />&quot;Stain&quot; follows up to &quot;Sliver,&quot; a fine example of the transition from &quot;Bleach&quot; to &quot;Nevermind.&quot;  &quot;Been a Son&quot; is a song obviously inspired by the Vaselines and has a great tune to it, and is very easy to sing along to.  &quot;Turnaround&quot; throws you for a loop stuck between two rather upbeat songs, but is great in its own right.<br />The next two songs on the album are &quot;Molly's Lips&quot; and &quot;Son of a Gun,&quot; both actually songs by the Vaselines.  I've listened to the original version of &quot;Molly's Lips,&quot; and I'll tell you that Nirvana brought their music from a song with just potential to two of the greatest songs I've ever heard.  I will never, ever get sick of those two songs.  They were, for me, completely worth the purchase price alone.<BR> <BR>&quot;(New Wave) Polly&quot; is a strange trip indeed, taking what we knew as a quiet acoustic song and blasts it in our ears at double-speed and electric guitar ablazing.  &quot;Beeswax&quot; and &quot;Downer&quot; are rather catchy and the choruses has me singing along every time I hear them.  They're not what you'd consider 'singalongable' but they still have that quality.<br />&quot;Mexican Seafood,&quot;  &quot;Hairspray Queen,&quot; and &quot;Aero Zeppelin&quot; were three of Kurt's first attempts at songwriting, at least with Nirvana.  They're all quite great, but I will give you fair warning:  &quot;Hairspray Queen&quot; will draw you in.  When you first listen to it, you'll be put off by his strange way of singing in this song.  But it's catchy bassline and riffs will draw you in and you'll begin to even enjoy his singing in this song, despite what you may think on first listen.<br />&quot;Big Long Now&quot; is a mildly haunting song that keeps you listening as it drags ever-so-slightly behind the tempo.  For some reason it reminds me a bit of a horror movie.  It's one of the standout tracks on the album.<br />The closer, &quot;Aneurysm,&quot; ends the album with a bang, ending a remarkable, catchy album with a remarkable, catchy song.  At the closing notes of this one, you'll be going for the Repeat button on your stereo.  I know that I do.<BR>

B00005JLSE|3.0|With the award for Best Picture and five other Academy Awards under its belt, I figured I would give Chicago a try even though I am not a big fan of musicals or films that are generally eaten up by the Academy Awards (I see the Oscars as more of a popularity contest than anything). I would have to say that I found the film visually wonderful. And I also really liked some of the performances, especially from Zeta-Jones. And I do have a respect for the choreograpy work that was put into this movie and the singing that was performed. But I felt that the film moved at an awkward pace. The movie kind of felt like a big flashy ride over an extremely bumpy road. It just seemed like the events of the story moved along rather fast and were blurred by the big musical/dance performances. And yes I do realize that this was based on a broadway musical and the story is really supposed to told through the musical performances, but I found it all to be distracting and misleading. And when the film ended, I had not a clue ten minutes before that the film was in its conclusion. But like I said, musicals are not my cup of tea and I can only judge and criticize to my own personal tastes. I absolutely can see why this film would be brilliant to others. I do have a big respect for Chicago, but I don't have to like it as much as I have to respect it.

B000003S0D|5.0|Lizard, with no doubt, is one of the masterpieces recorded by Fripp and colleagues in early 70's. This album, and In The Court of the Crimson King, deserves all attentions from prog fans and rock'n roll listeners. An album full of strong jazzistic influences, filled with all melancolic mood that Crimson brought to prog rock early in 1969.<br />This line-up recorded only this album, but we can feel that they know how to put things together, improvise and really kicks off !!! Mr. Fripp is more concentrated in direct the music, not using all his odd, freaky and complex guitar abilities. Instead of it, he's using some nice acoustic guitars (only heard this way in Lizard) and his Mellotron is sounding heavenly ! (as in all early Crimson albums!). Mel Collins are playing very complex tunes and some disarmonious chords in his saxophones and flutes. These guy was, undoubtly, a strong reinforcement in Crimson's team. <br />Haskel, although having weak vocals, knows how to play melodic and simple bass lines, that perfectly fits in Fripp and Collin's crazyness! McCulloch was a very nice surprise. His jazz-like drumming reminds Michel Giles, with a little bit more complexity. Him, Collins and Fripp drives Lizard trough a marvelous prog-jazz-avant-garde record! Lizard, with the two previous albums, are simply much more prog rock with high quality Crimson song than Islands, from 71, or any other album after Red, from 74.<br />Cirkus and Happy Family are examples of complex structured tracks, with nice melodies, jazzy harmonies and dramatic lyrics. The Mellotron-driven track Circkus is among Crimson's best track ever, really dramatically strong track. Sinfield wrote one of his best lyrics for Lizard, and it's maybe Cirkus, altough all the lyrics fits very well in the album's mood. Indoor Games is an excellent track, McCulloch and Collins works gently in the central line, and it's reminds me some be-bop thing with a rock'n roll bass line. The track Lizard, with it's 23 mins, is a classic Crimson track. No other Crimson album has a long and diverse track like Lizard. Jon Anderson, as a guest, gave a beautiful contibution to the delicate melody of the first part. The Bolero part is Crimson in its all complexity and dramaticity, very strong mellotron overtures and saxophones. <br />Simply a magestic track. <br />With strong lyrics, very nice and different tunes, played by high skill musicians made Lizard a classic album from 70's and for Crimson's career. Together with In the Court of the Crimson King and In the Wake of Poseidon, these records are OBLIGATORY listening for all prog rock and avant-garde music fans ! We should remind that Larks' and Red are MASTERPIECES, but that's another story...

B0000AI44Q|5.0|Mature and developed, \\"Greendale\\" is less a rock album than a fully realized novel.  Once again with something to say and with conviction to fuel it, Neil has created a town, a cast of characters and a set of individual histories that he relates in a manner akin to Garrison Keillor's \\"Lake Wobegon\\" or Wilder's \\"Our Town\\".  More than simply a set of anecdotes, however, with \\"Greendale\\" Neil is able to show the effects that the Patriot Act's paranoia and the media-fueled self-consciousness have had on ordinary folks just getting by in America.  From the opening of \\"Falling From Above\\", with Grandpa and Cousin Jed chewing the fat on the porch until the climactic transformation of the sweet granddaughter, Sun Green, into an inspired activist against oil drilling in the Alaskan arctic in \\"Be The Rain\\", Crazy Horse's crunching music provides the perfect backdrop for Neil's lyrics which offer everyday images to bring attention to injustices being committed (ostensibly) in our name by individuals of power and influence. Perhaps the starkest song on the cd, \\"Bandit\\" quietly and elegantly expresses a certain desperation that comes at the end of one's rope, right before Earl finds the strength to go on.  The characters all seem to find that strength, even the widow of Officer Carmichael who was gunned down in \\"Leave the Driving\\" and Grandpa when he attempts to chase the reporters off his porch in \\"Grandpa's Interview\\".  Perhaps that's Neil's theme after all.<br />There are no likely hit songs on this album (though they are all catchy in a Crazy Horse way), no four-color posters, and no commercial sell-outs to the folks at Clear Communications (who also seem in the cross-hairs).  This is an album of powerful music, potent lyrics, and intelligent thoughts given expression through distorted and tough rock and roll.  The Bonus DVD of a solo acoustic show is a pleasant extra, if tangential to the CD content, and the little storybook that accompanies the set is charmingly incoherent.  Despite these perhaps-unnecessary extras, the album itself rises far above anything he's released in a long time (\\"Tonight's the Night\\" perhaps?) and certainly stands apart from most contemporary music releases.<br />This album is a must for Neil/Crazy Horse fans, a must for alternative/college music lovers, definitely the one to get for budding activists and aging boomers who remember Chicago '68, or even for rock fans who love a good story, but \\"Greendale\\" is probably not the best cd for someone looking for pop drivel, the grotesque, or just plain ol' beer-swilling tunes.

B0000646UN|1.0|I've seen many, many war movies over the years, and as much as I was looking forward to this one, The Winter War turned out to be one of the worst war films I've ever seen. This film does have two important things going for it: it's one of the only movies about this conflict that you're likely to see, and it features extensive and graphic big-budget combat scenes. The movie pulls no punches about the nastiness of war. <br />Unfortunately, this film has so many huge problems that it can only be recommended to extremely forgiving viewers with a particular interest in this conflict. First of all, the story is remarkably flimsy; it's really just a very loose framework on which to hang a bunch of numbingly repetitive battle scenes. Some grognards (fanatical war buffs, basically) rave about this movie because of its battle scenes. Sure, they're graphic and have lots of explosions, but when they're so poorly written, directed, and edited, who cares? Don't expect to find anything as masterly filmed or emotionally intense as the openings of Saving Private Ryan or Enemy at the Gates, for example. Meanwhile, characters, themes, and plot twists are never fleshed out or are simply nonexistent. <br />Just as bad, the directing and editing are literally some of the worst I've ever seen in a feature film: jerky or downright incoherent cuts between shots and scenes are more the norm than the exception. These affect not merely the combat scenes, but the whole film. The Winter War looks downright amateurish much of the time. (Other reviewers claim that much material has been deleted for this DVD release, and it sure looks that way!) Also, the acting is merely acceptable here, which makes it that much harder to care about any of the characters and whether they live or die. On top of that, the subtitles are poorly handled: they're littered with grammatical and spelling errors. Finally, the DVD transfer looks like it came from some third-generation video tape.<br />If you're looking fora modern, realistic WWII film on DVD, you'd do far better with the Band of Brothers miniseries, Saving Private Ryan, Das Boot, The Thin Red Line, Stalingrad, or Enemy at the Gates, for example. Those all feature far better writing, acting, direction, editing, and/or cinematography. Those are films that both grognards and film buffs can enjoy.<br />For those who just want to gawk at some early-war Soviet tanks and trench warfare, The Winter War might be of interest, but that sure doesn't make it a good film. Hopefully the film will be released properly some day, so we can judge the real thing instead of this mess of a movie.

B000002J09|5.0|This album is crazy... I'll take it song by song:<br />Black Dog: chaotic, catchy, and unbelievably complex, this song is one that you don't mind getting stuck in your head<br />Rock and Roll: an absolute classic beginning with the unmistakable snare intro, this simple but masterful piece is heard on Cadillac commercials these days<br />Battle of Evermore: a more eclectic turn (as can always be expected from Zeppelin), this tune is a mandolin-based parallel to the final battle sequence of The Return of the King (LOTR), with several spine-tingling climaxes<br />Stairway to Heaven: what must I say? It's the best song ever heard by human ears, topped off with the ultimate, nothing-short-of-perfect solo by none other than the Pagemaster himself. Seriously - this song is the real deal. I recommend only listening to it when you have the time for the full 8:00.<br />Misty Mountain Hop: definitely not \\"cooked-up\\" in two minutes.., this song is probably the closest Zeppelin ever got to pop music. It's catchy, surprisingly complex to play, and also another LOTR parallel, this time from the beginning of The Hobbit.<br />Four Sticks: a personal favorite of mine, this song is most likely inspired by Zeppelin's frequent treks around the English country side. Watch for the cool synth part, and the absolute genius whail put out by Plant after the final chorus. You'll know it because it sounds so ridiculously cool.<br />Going to California: a Zeppelin staple acoustic set, this is the softest moment of the album. Though quiet and simple, this song always seems to leave an impression.<br />When the Levee Breaks: a bold and stark song that seems to be one of the best examples of the huge sound Page was able to create by placing mics farther away from his guitar than was custom. Watch for the \\"Don't it make you feel bad...\\" portion, being the only record of Plant singing in a yelling/aggressive manner. A sweet song, altogether. <br />This is the finest album ever recorded, by the finestband, including the finest guitarist, of any genre. Buy it (and don't burn it, for crying out loud).
B00007JMCX|5.0|It's a shame that only 5 stars can be given to this classic film.<BR>David Bowie, whom I adore anyway, makes an excellent debut in this superb film.<br />The film follows Walter Tevis's novel very well and adapts to the screen to create a very saddening tale of corporate America and how it can be a boon or a bust to some, including aliens.<br />That alone is a scary thought.<br />Upon his arrival from a dying planet, Thomas Jerome Newton sets out to create an empire to obtain money to purchase water for his dying planet.  Occasional scenes are shown of him leaving his wife and children behind, and throughout the film we see other scenes of them waiting for his return.<br />What is never shown is how he is going to transport this to his home planet.<br />Along the way to his path to success, he is plagued by metaphorical leeches who will do anything to stop him. Greed, lust, and several other deadly sins are thrust upon our protaganist as he tries in vain to overcome them in the process.<br />David Bowie was the perfect person to be cast for this movie.  He moves along in it with an icy perfection that is or was appropriate to his character at the time.<br />Keep in mind, this film is not without it's flaws.  Some scenes were restored to make this the original theatrical release.  One involving Rip Torn and his student could have been done without as  it makes no sense and attributes nothing to the overall affect of the movie.  Again, that is just an opinion, and die hard fans of this movie will be happy that it is included.<br />This film, upon it's release, was well ahead of its time and to this day, many of the themes implied still are appropiate to what constitutes success vs. failure in the American business sense.<br />The films ends on a saddening note, however, and should be a reminder that what goes around, comes around.  You do not have to be a fan of David Bowie to appreciate this film, he just makes it all work and the end result is stunning.  Nicholas Roeg did everything possible to steer away from the persona of David Bowie and his music.  The end result is a very good solid acting part on his behalf.  Ironically, some of the incidental music later became working pieces on David Bowie's LOW album, which has a stunning shot from the movie.  Highly recommended, and not for anyone looking for a quick plot or storyline and a happy ending, this film is chock full of storylines and plots that keeps you interested throughtout it's prescence.

B00005JLK1|4.0|A lot of horror fans don't think too highly of this film, but I quite enjoyed my time on the Ghost Ship.  Maybe there's nothing too original or ground-breaking about the type of horror it has to offer, but that doesn't mean it's not effective and entertaining.  Certainly, believability is a weakness in a few spots, and I'm still trying to figure out how a couple of \\"facts\\" could have been even remotely possible, but the film does create an eerie atmosphere and doesn't mind spilling a little blood in pursuit of its ends.<br />I think I can safely say that the opening scene of the movie is rather unforgettable, and I greatly admire the effect the moviemakers were going for here.  Rarely does a movie purport to take out untold scores of people with one swift blow, and it is most unfortunate that a lack of commitment to this potentially extraordinary scene sets in motion the very doubts and misgivings some viewers have of the real meat of the story.  The method of mass execution used in this first scene is pretty hard to accept scientifically, but the real problem comes in the form of some very obvious mannequins lying among the \\"dead.\\"  The filmmakers try to salvage the scene by having the victims take a few moments to figure out that they are quite dead, and that works for me; unfortunately, they take this too far and end up making what should be a glorious bloodbath look a little silly.<br />The real story here concerns the crew of a salvage boat hired to salvage a mysterious old ship that a pilot claims to have spotted in the Bering Sea.  What they find is an Italian ocean liner missing for forty years, but the great riches they discover onboard lead not to the paradise on earth they fantasize about but rather its exact opposite.  Trapped on board the dead vessel, each crew member must fight to stay alive and sane in an environment which quickly shows itself to be quite haunted indeed.  The fates of a few are rather hokey and predictable, but the storyline around one little girl ghost saves the movie in my opinion.  Only Maureen Epps (Julianna Margulies) can see little Katie (played quite effectively by Emily Browning), who eventually tells her the story of what happened forty years ago.  This little girl, a pure-hearted ghost trapped on a ship full of malevolent spirits, certainly does her share to give the movie the creepy aura it needs.  The major flashback we see through the eyes of Katie, though, is just plain weird.  As we are transported back forty years in time, we are suddenly bombarded by some type of hard-driving, neo-tech electronic music that seems wholly out of place.<br />I'm not saying Ghost Ship does not have its faults and weaknesses, but in my opinion it made for an entertaining albeit rather predictable little horror movie.  Some people seem to hate the ending, but I had no problem with it whatsoever; I think it worked quite well in the context of everything I had just seen.  I would not call Ghost Ship a must-see horror film by any means, nor do I personally consider it all that gory, but I do think it has enough chills and thrills to satisfy or at least entertain many a horror fan out there.one little girl ghost saves the movie in my opinion. This little girl, a pure-hearted ghost trapped on a ship full of malevolent spirits, certainly does her share to give the movie the creepy aura it needs.  The major flashback we see through the eyes of Katie, though, is just plain weird. Some people seem to hate the ending, but I had no problem with it whatsoever; I think it worked quite well in the context of everything I had just seen.  I would not call Ghost Ship a must-see horror film by any means, nor do I personally consider it all that gory, but I do think it has enough chills and thrills to satisfy or at least entertain many a horror fan out there.
B00005KHJR|5.0|Few movies from England, with the exception of Hammer Films, have had any profound affect in the United States, especially in the horror genre.  This film, however, in spite of its age, (released in 1974 in a shorter version than filmed) is one of the exceptions.<br />Filmed on location in Scotland, this startling tale begins as an innocent romp through a Celtic forum and quickly proceeds to some startling practices and beliefs in Celtic themes.<br />A police officer has been notified of a child who has gone missing on Summerisle.  He proceeds to investigate this and is given the slip on several occasions, which prompts him to believe there is a   <BR>conspiracy surrounding this event.  Much to his disbelief, there is.<br />After witnessing several bizarre events himself, he believes that this missing child may be a part of a pagan sect which will ensure that the coming harvest will be prosperous.  <br />Beautiful photography, music and scenery only enhance this somewhat murder mystery.  The ending is only for those who need to see it as it is not what anyone expects at all.  Pay attention, however, and you MAY figure it out!  Highly recommended viewing, some brief nudity and sexual overtones gave this an R rating and is not recommended for the younger audience. It is an adventure with someone with a different voice.  Amusing, sad, this book is a delight. If you don't know anything about indviduals with high functioning autism, you can get more insight from this novel than from texts and articles dealing with the subject. If you have had experience with autism before, there are many opportunities to identify with Christopher and his parents. Not nearly as much screaming as I wanted, no really catchy riffs that I noticed, and the lyrics are just too damn creepy. I don't mind weird, as I've heard all of Around the Fur, but there's fine line between oddly melodic and freakishly weird, and for a lot of the songs on here, deftones leaps over it. It is pretty good, though, but listen to all the songs on their website (they let you listen to the whole album), and then decide if it's worth your money. I love passenger, feticetera, and back to school, and some of the parts on the other songs I like, so that's what gave it the three stars.
B00008EY5W|4.0|I despised Starship Troopers when it first came out. I thought it was adolescent, ultra-violent, proto-fascist garbage. Boy, was I wrong. Yes, it's packed with gore and at first glance it could be misconstrued as a celebration of Nazi-style militarism. But here's a news bulletin: IT'S SATIRE, PEOPLE! I swear, Paul Verhoven is a freakin' genius. This is not your run-of-the-mill School of Saturday Night Live broad satire. This is a bit more subtle than that. It also happens to be a kickass sci-fi action blockbuster. It's great storytelling, with a wry, well-crafted screenplay. It's a fully realized world within itself. And never let it be said that Mr. Verhoven doesn't know how to cast the hotties.<br />Some people have complained that there is precious little science in this science fiction rollercoaster. They're right. Verhoven has thrown logic and science right out the window. But that's OK--he wasn't trying for the \\"2001: A Space Odyssey, There's No Sound in Outer Space Award\\". But if you can check your Inner Physicist at the door and just enjoy the ride, this movie is a blast. Technically, the CGI special effects were state-of-the-art in 1997 and they still look great, especially in Superbit. So donate your copies of Phantom Menace and Attack of the Clones to the Goodwill. They're tedious [stuff]. Buy this movie--it's one fun flick.
B000001DTM|5.0|U2's popularity at the time at which they released &quot;Achtung Baby&quot; was at a highpoint, and then they did something unexpected: they totally changed the sonic landscape of their music, trading in a guitars/bass/drums/vocals sound that had become justly celebrated for an electronica-inspired fusion of hard rock and ambient sound.  They would eventually take that sound even further (witness &quot;Pop&quot; and &quot;Passengers&quot;), but never with as much controversy as on &quot;Achtung Baby.&quot;  Many of their most ardent fans abandoned them, feeling that they had gone off the deep end.<br />What U2 did not change one iota with this album was their emphasis on emotionality in their music.  As a result, they ended up with what was their finest album to date.  U2 has never been better than they are on &quot;One,&quot; and the dark emotion of that song is a mere prelude to the content of songs such as &quot;Ultraviolet,&quot; &quot;So Cruel,&quot; &quot;Acrobat,&quot; and &quot;Love Is Blindness.&quot;  Also, since U2 is a rock band, there are several songs that, well, rock: &quot;Even Better Than the Real Thing,&quot; &quot;Mysterious Ways,&quot; &quot;Who's Gonna Ride Your Wild Horses,&quot; and &quot;The Fly.&quot;<br />This is a landmark of an album, one that should be bought and listened to by anyone who loves rock and roll.

B00005JLSE|3.0|'Chicago' was probably a great stage musical. On-screen the plot is too flimsy, the dialogue and action too campy even for one who usually loves camp, i.e. me. Dancing was fine, the direction & effects were truly impressive, singing was good, songs were good. But no more than good. Not great. And after seeing it, I had no desire to ever see it again or to hum any of the songs. It was imminently forgettable. This film seems to be more about showcasing the hidden musical/dancing talents of actors known solely for acting than about a plausible story. The wit is superficial at best, and the moral of the story is a real yawner (if you even think there is one). If this is supposed to be the movie that brings back musicals, I think I'll just rerun some of the old classics instead. I dunno, I always think the Oscar winner for best picture should be one that will stand the test of time, e.g. Casablanca, The Sting, etc. I really don't think this movie can do that. All that aside, kudos to the one real singing talent I did see: Queen Latifah's acting may have been a trifle wooden but on stage she stole the entire movie with the one song she had. That was the only memorable scene IMHO. Otherwise, a very mediocre movie. I gave the DVD away the day after I watched it.

B0000DCGT0|4.0|You will be transported to an earlier time. It is sad to say many in our day and time is clueless as to what it would be like to be willing to do ANY job just to survive. The Great Depression affects most people in that one day they were good upstanding people and the next day they are riding in rail cars, or giving their children away in hopes that they will have better prospects than they themselves.<br /><br />Seabiscuit is the story of four broken individuals, A business man with a hole in his heart, a horseman who has no way to ply his trade, and a young man who found himself as a pick up boxer (unsuccessful), a jockey who can quote Shakespeare to his fellow jockey, and a broken and abused throwaway horse that was but a moment away from a bullet in the head. The country had been ravaged by hard times and needed to have a down and outer to become an up and comer; they needed a reason to cheer. Seabiscuit gave them a reason.<br /><br />This movie is about these four individuals finding wholeness again. It is a movie that reminds us that to get back up again is honorable and even feasible provided you believe in yourself even if others do not. Seabiscuit is beautifully filmed and well acted. Jeff Bridges, Toby McGuire and Chris Cooper are perfect for their roles.<br /><br />Do yourself a favor and see this wonderful film -- watch it on those days when you need a reason to cheer.
0385504209|2.0|The ending of this book left me so disappointed and frustrated. What a cop out! The book was brilliant, had me enthralled the whole way through, but to follow a journey to unearth something for 450 pages, sharing the vicarious thrill of each new discovery leading to the location of that something, and then at the very end, to neatly avoid any kind of revelation with a touchy-feely 'Oh, actually, it's better if people DON'T learn the truth--it's better if we DON'T unearth this amazing historical, groundbreaking treasure we've been searching for because people are probably happier not knowing.' HUH???<br />Talk about the coward's way out--both for the author AND the protagonist. I really could not believe the author did that to the reader...then again, it makes sense if what's on his mind is just cranking out sequels about this character. In other words, if the Da Vinci Code had actually followed through with its groundbreaking discovery, the world and the church would be a different place than it is now, and maybe Dan Brown is not comfortable trying to write sequels in a setting that seems abstract to him. But all I thought at the end of this book was that I had been strung along for NOTHING--and furthermore, I will not put myself through it again with Angels &amp; Demons, which is going right back to the store!
B00005JM09|4.0|I didn't know whether or not this movie would be good, but I went to see it out of loyalty to the Terminator franchise.  I was pleasantly surprised.  Bringing back Skynet via government research, despite the destruction of Cyberdyne, was actually quite clever - it emphasizes the theory that every event carries infinite different outcomes, and just because Cyberdyne was destroyed does not necessarily rule out the possibility that Skynet will arise by other means.  It may seem like a cheesy plot trick to many, but in actuality it is well-rooted in currently existing theories about temporal mechanics.  Also, the T-X was quite good - not just in physical appearance.  The character was well-played and definitely lived up to Robert Patrick's T-1000 from T2.  Some people have expressed discontent over the label \\"Terminatrix\\", but I want to emphasize that the T-X was never officially identified as the Terminatrix by Skynet or by Arnold Schwarzenegger's character.  It is a label created by John Connor, who was at least partially sarcastic in calling the T-X a Terminatrix.  The official designation of the T-X is T-X; the X can stand for a number of things - experimental; some sort of new labelling system; or X as in the X chromosome, indicating that the T-X adopts a female appearance.  The end of the movie is an interesting and intriguing twist as well - I definitely recommend it to everyone, especially those who didn't quite feel like there was complete closure at the end of T2.

B000002WU9|5.0|Although he is arguably the best story-teller in the highly seminal and gargantuan rap collective, The Wu Tang Clan, and perhaps the entire hip-hop industry, Raekwon the Chef is rarely regarded as a rap legend. A couple listens, and \\"Cuban Linx\\" should prove to any skeptics that Rae is all talent, no hype. Backed by a thick soundscape courtesy of master beatsmith RZA, Rae delivers heartbreaking tales of wealthy hustling kingpins being murdered by stick-up kids, hustlers rising through the ranks of the underworld and entering the realms of high-stakes drug dealing, and the desperation of young black males that leads them towards criminal lifestyles. He does all of this with eery emotional detachment, a been-there-done that attitude, and a novelist's eye for detail. Rae is accompanied by a slew of members from the Wu Tang Clan, most notably Ghostface Killah featured on most of the songs, whose often tongue-and-cheek rhyme style plays off perfectly to Rae's unflinching seriousness. Ghost's presence never prevents Rae from shining, and the audience still knows who the album belongs to. Although Raekwon proves himself to be a master at his craft, the album would still be nothing without the consistently fascinating sounds churned out by RZA, who employs sound clips from John Woo's film \\"The Killer,\\" and De Palma's gangster classic \\"Scarface.\\" The beats do almost as much as Rae's lyrical vision, to reinvent the Wu Tang Clan as a righteous mafia family. \\"Cuban Linx\\" is arguably the greatest concept album in hip-hop, with a cold, grimy atmosphere that vividly conjures images of an icy New York winter. After listening to the album, it is easy to see how Rae's style of vivid high-stakes drug deal storytelling has influenced many New York rappers since he was first heard rapping on \\"Enter the Wu Tang,\\" although he does address this with some anger on the skit \\"Shark Niggas [Biters].\\" Some highlights on this flawless album include the heartbreaking \\"Knowledge God,\\" the highly detailed \\"Incarcerated Scarfaces,\\" the excellent remix of \\"Can it Be So Simple,\\" the chilling introspection on \\"Rainy Dayz,\\" the posse cut \\"Wu Gambinos,\\" and of course, Rae's testament to his love of a good woman, \\"Ice Cream. In the end, Raekwon's 1995 classic will never truly get the credit it deserves from American hip hop fans, but nonetheless it remains an essential to any fan of true-school hardcore rap. Pick it up.
0385504209|5.0|This is the first book by Dan Brown that I have read, and I was really impressed with the research he did on numerous topics to make his book a page turner.<br />I will do my own research on The Priory of Sion, Opus Dei, and the alleged marriage of Christ and Mary Magdalene.  I am a catholic and have had my doubts about the religious teachings I received as a child, so reading Dan Brown's opinion does not necessarily sway me from mine.  It just makes me want to know more about what the church forbade me to read when I was in elementary school, high school and college.<br />  But, I ask this question:  What is truth?  &quot;A man convinced against his will is of the same opinion still&quot;... sorry but I don't remember where I read this missive.  Anyway, this book is fiction with a lot of factual information used to provoke the reader's mind to thought.<br />  So what if there are contradictions, and inaccuracies?  Dan Brown has written an amazing detective story that is thrilling and instructive at the same time.  He has my vote.
B0000039PW|5.0|Wanna know how to create a rap album that will achieve classic status on the streets and on the charts? Look no further than the Notorious B.I.G.'s 1994 classic \\"Ready to Die.\\" The album is backed by amazing beats, contains party anthems for the MTV crowd, lyrical depth, introspection, ghetto storytelling/analysis unequaled elsewhere. \\"Ready to Die\\" is undoubtedly a pop music phonomenon. Although many will argue that Biggie peaked on his sophomore effort, in my opinion, that album isn't nearly as raw, honest, and powerful as his debut. The album's first track \\"Things Done Changed\\" (intro excluded) establishes the environment Biggie is going to take the audience to--Bed-Stuy, Brooklyn. Biggie's world is a violent one, and he knows it, making him constantly wary and fearful of jealous traitors and oppressive cops or anyone \\"trying to drop my decimals.\\" On \\"Gimme the Loot,\\" Big Poppa displays the Darwinist dog-eat-dog mentality he needs to maintain for survival. He's honest and even funny about it despite its heavy social implications. In \\"Warning,\\" Biggie fills a couple of foolish would-be-assassins with bullets, and later on \\"Everyday Struggle,\\" Biggie details the stressful flipside of the criminal lifestyle. What eventually makes this album special is that where most rappers would wallow in a morose state of frustration Biggie is still irresistably smooth, clever, funny, charming, and even upbeat. Biggie is a nasty ghetto teddybear, with a violent temper and cold calculating business sensibilities. Even though much of the album deals with heavy subject matter, Biggie still knows how to get his party on, and establishes the Big Poppa playa persona on \\"Big Poppa,\\" and \\"One More Chance.\\" And \\"Juicy\\" is still the quintessential underdog anthem. If party anthems and tales of slum-life aren't your thing, there's still a lot of good old-fashioned rhyme spitting on the hardcore banger \\"Machine Gun Funk,\\" and the amazing collabo with Method Man, \\"The What.\\" While the album contains diverse moods and subject matter, it is marked by Biggie's serious foreboding and paranoia (he can't even trust the women he parties with). It seems as if he knows that the inevitable result of his lifestyle is either incarceration or more likely, death. A stunning album of epic proportions. Biggie doesn't sacrafice any of his hardcore edge for commercial success, as he did, in my opinion, on his second effort. The album is a brutally honest tale of a hustler's troubled ascent to superstardom brimming with paranoia and regret, yet strangely uplifting. A hip hop landmark, and musical miracle, pick it up.

B00006CXXU|5.0|I have been a Christina fan from the very beginning, infact, even before her self-titled first CD hit the stores when her hit Reflection was released a year earlier to incorporate with the theme of the Disney movie, Mulan. After Christina put out her first CD and her Spanish version (and the Christmas CD), she disappeared. I didn't know what happened to her. But last fall when I heard about her comeback I was very happy and excited. Of course she made a startling comeback with her sensual romping in 'Dirrty' (which I loved but raised many eyebrows in the industry and caused its banning from many TV stations and radio stations). I got the CD two months later for Christmas. I LOVED it. It's one of my favorite CDs, if not my favorite. <br />Stripped--an excellent piece set with many clips and pieces of interviews and newscasters in the background talking about Christina's scandalous career that introduces us to the new and real Christina. <br />Can't Hold Us Down--Not crazy about the Lil' Kim piece but everything else I really liked and enjoyed, with a great message for girls around the world. <br />Walk Away--One of my favorites. The haunting lyrics and melody really can put you in a sad state of feeling. The deep meaning and background of the song is very powerful <br />Fighter--A new twist of music for Christina: this song is actually a rock song. I loved the video and it truly fits with the song which is very dark and not all pop Britney Spears stuff. <br />Interlude--brings back memories of Christina's Latin album. Good introduction to Infatuation, if only I could understand the words. <br />Infatuation--sounds like one of Christina's earlier songs but it's still a good piece and would be great to dance to. <br />Loving Me For Me Interlude--sweet and soft lyrics and beat. The bird sounds in the background and the waterfall make it a nice introduction to Loving For Me. <br />Loving Me For Me--Great song, good lyrics and beat. Shows us once again how many styles Christina can manage on one album.<br />Impossible--Not one of my favorites but is very dynamic and powerful. A great rendition and duo with Alicia Keys. <br />Underappreciated--Good upbeat song with not such an upbeat message. A favorite, sounds very soulful and R & B like. <br />Beautiful--A favorite. Beautiful song (hence the name?) and if you ever feel down listen to this song and you will be smiling again just like in the video. <br />Make Over--Loud and rock like. Lots of curses thrown around. Not a favorite but still a very dynamic piece that shows off Christina and her singing capabilities. <br />Cruz--Good song with a somewhat independent message to teens.  <br />Soar--Not a favorite but has a great message about being yourself and not falling to the standards of others. Soulful and inspiring. <br />Get Mine, Get Yours--A favorite. Sexual lyrics, a sort of softer version of Dirrty. The song is simple, talks about sex. The innocent Christina is gone. <br />Dirrty--Favorite song on the CD. Loud, raunchy, sexual, sensual, and ravishing. I love the video as a counterpart. This song was bashed a lot but who cares, this is the real Christina and she should be able to express herself freely. <br />Stripped 2--Nice message, a continuation of Stripped, the first song. Reveals Christina's sexuality. <br />Voice Within--For some reason whenever I listen to this song it makes me feel a little sad and depressed and unhopeful. A good song though and Christina belts out a nice few notes. <br />I'm Ok--A sad haunting song. The melody, the cries of Christina in the background, and the sad message of Christina's childhood abuse will make you feel for Christina. <br />Keep on Singing My Song--Good closing song and piece for this CD. Not a favorite but the dynamics are great. You go girl! <br />All in all, I loved this CD. Christina is back and better than ever! Great job Christina and keep on singing your song!

The music has almost a Mirror Ball-ish feel to it in the production and roughness, but that's a good thing. Especially coming after Are You Passionate, this album is great!

B00000IP3S|4.0|This was a great pick up for me as I got it off my brother for four bucks.  He was dumping some of his old metal CD's and I took advantage.  Needless to say, I have rarely gotten such a return on four dollars as I have with this album.  My favorite song on the album is the title track, which is one of my favorite Blind Guardian songs ever.  Bright eyes is a pretty good song too, a strong power ballad, although without the usual power ballad type lyrics.  In fact the lyrics for much of this album are pretty out there, hence the title.  As a whole this album mixes thrash metal with slower, more deliberate power metal.  My favorite of the three 'thrash' songs on the album is probably I'm Alive.  The other two, Born in a mourning hall and Another holy war don't do as much for me but are still good.  My least favorite song is probably Mordred's song.  It seems a little flat compared to some of the others.  But that's just my opinion.  It will probably be someone's favorite but I personally don't listen to it as much as the other tracks.<br />  At any rate, be sure to buy this album, especially if you are a fan of Arthurian literature.  This album is the closest thing I've seen to a heavy metal soundtrack for 'The Once and Future King'.  Additionally, if you like this album but are in the mood for something a little heavier(as my brother obviously was) then I suggest Iced Earth.  They are somewhat similar but have more of a heavier core with heavier riffs that stand out more whereas Blind Guardian are more focused on epic vocals.
0812036034|3.0|Reading this play is not too interesting. There are a lot of visual elements in this play such as ship wrecks, dancing fairies, the use of magic, and an ugly monster. The themes of power, freedom and forgiveness are touched upon.<br />Propero has had his kingdom usurped by his brother and he seeks to regain his kingdom by the use of his magic. His brother Antonio and company are purposely shipwrecked on the island that Prospero has been banished to. One of the shipwrecked company is a son of a king named Ferdinand who falls in love at first sight with Prospero's daughter Miranda and he becomes a slave to Prospero. Typical Shakesphearian love at first sight silliness ensues.<br />Prospero has another slave, a monster named Caliban. Caliban is an interesting character with some of the best lines in the play. He seeks to regain the island back from Prospero with the help of two lowly comic characters, Trinculo and Stephano. This part is faintly funny to read about.<br />Eventually the play wraps up with the gruff, overbearing, cantankerous, and somewhat cruel windbag Prospero forgiving his brother's trespasses, regaining his kingdom, and stifling Caliban's rebellion. And, of course, no Shakespheare play is complete without a marraige--this time Miranda and Ferdinand will be wed. Prospero also frees his trusty servant-fairy Ariel and having accomplished all this, mentions that he is ready to die.<br />Prospero is a psychologically complex character worth reading about. I also liked the scene in which his betraying brother Antonio seeks to subtlely persuade Sebastian to kill Alonso, the duke of Naples, and capture his kingdom. It had a lot of moody, dramatic tension to it. But for the most part I couldn't get into this play.

6303165680|5.0|Rowan Atkinson, who plays the nervous and shy Father Gerald, speaks those lines at a wedding.  His writing partner, Richard Curtis, wrote this sweet, good-natured comedy of a circle of friends, all in their thirties, who attend weddings and gradually wonder the mysteries of love.  Is it better to hold out for that ideal person or as the bumbling, nice, but not exactly fashion-modellish Tom puts it, \\"I always just hoped that, that I'd meet some nice friendly girl, like the look of her, hope the look of me didn't make her physically sick, then pop the question and, um, settle down and be happy.\\"  The follies of finding anyone just to prevent from being lonely is also explored here, but so is the chain reaction that occurs at weddings, i.e. other people in turn end up getting married in serendipitous circumstances.<br />The opening scenes to the first marriage of the various friends getting ready, set to an Elton John song, sets the stage for the story.  The scenes of the slow-rising Charles and his female roommate Scarlett result in a series of comical scenes that elicit the f-word from them both, including missing the offramp leading to the wedding site.<br />It's at the first wedding that Cupid launches a projectile at Charles (Hugh Grant) via Carrie (Andie McDowell), an American who appears at the wedding with a big black hat.  What might have been a missed opportunity later turns depressing for Charles when he finds out she's engaged.  Indeed, he has a history of ex-girlfriends that leads the sensitive Henrietta to call him a serial monogamist.  But Charles is bewildered with awe at people who are actually ready to take that lifelong committment.  After all, despite divorce being commonplace, the sanctity of wedding still carries importance.  Both Grant's goofy and McDowell's sweet and lovable performances lift this film up, with the latter's winning smile, but they're not the only ones.<br />Fiona (Kristin Scott Thomas), nicknamed Fi or even Fifi, has a dignified beauty colored by a cynical tongue.  In the first wedding, when Scarlett gushes over the bride, she says, \\"Scarlett, you're blind.  She looks like a big meringue.\\"  She also unleashes her tart tongue at meek Father Gerald, training to be a priest.  She says it's rather like the first time one has sex, \\"a lot less messy of course, and far less call for condoms.\\"  Gerald titters with nervous laughter.<br />Of the other characters, Gareth, played by Simon Callow, is flamboyant, simply jovial, full of life, a true romantic, someone it's fun to hang around and be merry with, and as we learn later, a culinary eccentric.  Seeing him cutting loose on the dance floor in the first wedding is a highlight.  He plays with the theory that marriage is the last gasp between two couples who have run out of things to say, then says that true love is the driving force behind marriage.<br />The pint-sized Scarlett (Charlotte Coleman) is another funny character.  She has a shock of short bright red hair, sings offkey at church, and gets flirty with strangers at weddings.  It was quite a shock when I heard of her death from an asthma attack last year.<br />And David, Charles's deaf brother who's quite a dish, also gains some laughs in the conversations he has with his brother, and also with a girl who fancies him enough to take sign language lessons.  Is that love or what?<br />Another bit of trivia.  According to Richard Curtis, Henrietta's nickname was toned down to Duckface for propriety.  Guess what it was originally going to be?  Hint:  Duck gets replaced by a word it rhymes with.  And for those who don't know, the poem read at the funeral is W.H. Auden's \\"Funeral Blues\\".<br />With winning performances all around, great lines, be they witty, acerbic, or poignant, Four Weddings And A Funeral is a funny, romantic, and heartwarming winner from director Mike Newell (Enchanted April, Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire [pending]).  It give me hope that someday, maybe somedayE And ifyou don't like it, your name is duckface.f you don't like it, your name is duckface.

B0000041DZ|4.0|On listening to the interpretation of Beethoven's Piano Sonatas, one has to realise and admire the fact that the self-educated Alfred Brendel seems to add something new to Beethoven. Although I do prefer the Beethoven Sonatas by Daniel Barenboim due to it's &quot;traditional&quot; style (a recital sticking very closely to Beethoven's sheetmusic- and enunciation notes, giving it a very peaceful and common-sensible glow), Brendel seems something to get used to. If I were to call Barenboim the &quot;traditional&quot; and thus &quot;conservative&quot; master-pianst, Brendel would probably have to be called the &quot;radical&quot; and thus &quot;progressive&quot; variation. This is a conclusion made whilst listening to the Brendel's very unique style, of combining very harsh and wooden-sounding notes with soft and cloudy sounding ones. Many people would condemn such playing to &quot;bad piano playing&quot;, but this, of course, is not the case. <br />Beethoven himself was a genius with a very much troubled life, and who's music is mainly recognised by a certain troubeld feel to it, due to the gigantic and quickly conjured up contrasts in tone (for instance, the third movement of his 17th sonata), volume (the first movement of the 23rd sonata, known as the &quot;Appassionata&quot; sonata) and speed (the first movement of his 8th sonata, also known as the &quot;Pathetique&quot; sonata). Brendel manages not only to play these notes in the way Beethoven intended them to be played, but he also applies his own, progressive feelings to the enunciation of the work. He mainly does this, by adding more speed to the piece, of by making the notes sound somewhat irregular (which, on listening closer to the piece, is definitley not so). <br />Brendel is thus able to positively take Beethoven beyond Beethoven, experiment with Beethoven and multiply Beethoven with Beethoven. Although sounding sometimes a bit experimental, this collection of Beethoven sonata is unmissable for any Beethoven fan.

B000002U8G|5.0|Before The Wall, before Dark Side of the Moon, Pink Floyd created a very different kind of masterpiece. While their later albums were a triumph of concept, it is on Meddle where one can hear the *musical* peak of Pink Floyd's career. This is not a concept album--it is a musical journey showing off a variety of musical styles. The lyrics do not demand--they suggest, and allow the music to do the rest of the talking. Perhaps the most wonderful thing about Meddle is the fact that the band was truly functioning as a *band* here. Everyone's talents can be clearly heard, and no one shouts anybody else down.<br />There is no such thing as filler, on Meddle. Bookended by the mindblowing tracks &quot;One of These Days&quot; and &quot;Echoes&quot;, the four &quot;interior&quot; tracks are severely underrated. &quot;A Pillow of Winds&quot; and &quot;Fearless&quot; are both pleasant, leisurely guitar-driven songs, and seem fairly well appreciated by fans. However, I believe that the much-maligned &quot;San Tropez&quot; and &quot;Seamus&quot; are also deserving of appreciation. &quot;San Tropez&quot; is particularly notable for some very unique Roger Waters vocals--rather optimistic and even a touch bluesy...a style he unfortunately never pursued after that point. &quot;Seamus&quot; gives a rare glimpse of the fun side of Pink Floyd, as well as a flashback to the band's origins as a blues cover band. This was never a song meant to be taken so seriously as some do. &quot;One of These Days&quot; is an explosive, energetic instrumental that perhaps foreshadows the angry, driven rock of Animals, but with only one lyric--a rare appearance by Nick Mason, whose processed vocals growl menacingly, &quot;One of these days, I'm going to cut you into little pieces!&quot;<br />The album's final piece, &quot;Echoes&quot;, may be Pink Floyd's greatest work ever. From first to last &quot;ping&quot;, this brilliant near-symphony is fantastic. Each bandsman's talents are clearly audible, even thesimple-yet-effective contributions of Nick Mason and Roger Waters. The vocal harmony of David Gilmour and Richard Wright is mesmerising. Without question, this song contains the best verse Mr. Waters ever wrote: &quot;Strangers passing in the street, by chance two separate glances meet, and I am you and what I see is me. And do I take you by the hand, and lead you through the land, and help me understand the best I can?&quot;<br />Unfortunately, this reminder to walk a mile in the other man's shoes was a lesson Mr. Waters forgot in later years, at the price of devastating consequences to the band's output and to the members themselves. This moment in Pink Floyd's history is therefore one-of-a-kind, completely irreplaceable. The entire album can be summed up by the &quot;jam&quot; sequence in &quot;Echoes&quot;. Never before, never again do the pieces fit together so seamlessly, each a joy on its own and in combination.

I shot a wedding in a dark church with this lens and hand held. even at 1/4-1/8 second got me acceptable sharpness. I also tried 1/2 sec but sharpness started to really drop off. Granted, for a lens that is not in Canon's &quot;L&quot; series, it's a great performer in helping me get acceptable sharpness where I couldn't before. It's a great lens to hone skills with before you jump in to the much more expensive &quot;L&quot; series pool...You get what you pay for

B0000AI44Q|5.0|I had the luck of attending Neil Young's &quot;Greendale&quot; concert on my birthday, (June 19), and left the concert completely impressed; nearly stunned.  The power of this man's words, combined with the raw guitar and simple instrumentation of his Crazy Horse comrades, was akin to an old-fashioned &quot;revival&quot; meeting.  I have never left a show with such a feeling of awe over the portrait Mr. Young creates with this musical masterpiece.  I won't go into the premise/concept of the cd as that should have been explained already.  Suffice it to say, Mr. Young has released a brilliant piece that describes the greed, media frenzy and destruction of the Earth we are &quot;all&quot; reeking on this planet.  His acerbic and biting style is sure to have you nodding your head in agreement.  Some critics have argued that his theater production at the concert was amateurish and that it was cheesy.  To this I say, I think that is the whole &quot;point&quot;.  When you look at the inane t.v. shows like &quot;American Idol&quot; and &quot;Joe Millionaire&quot; you can't help but realize this is all a big distraction to keep us from seeing &quot;what's really going on.&quot;  And what's really going on is the planet is choking on its own excesses, the media focuses on the &quot;entertainment&quot; aspect of news to amuse us and we all live lives of quiet desperation, (though we don't take it as far as Jed, I hope).  Shades of Orwell creep into the lyrics of &quot;Leave the Driving&quot; with the lines, &quot;And we'll be watching you, no matter what you do, and you can do your part, by watching others too&quot;, (John Ashcroft should love it!).  Other lyrics that struck me as prophetic are from &quot;Grandpa's Interview&quot;: &quot;It ain't a privilege to be on tv, and it ain't a duty either, The only good thing about tv, is shows like &quot;Leave it to Beaver&quot;.  In a world of slick productions and deceitful marketing ploys, this music stands out because it is neither.  In a world full of corporate sell-outs and big business weasels, this cd differentiates itself from the rest by being honest and heart-felt.  ...

B00009P1O0|5.0|With &quot;On the Beach,&quot; Neil Young sent a signal to the millions of fans he accumulated with classic recordings like &quot;Everybody Knows this is Nowhere,&quot; &quot;After the Gold Rush,&quot; and &quot;Harvest&quot;-- the fans who packed stadiums to watch him perform as part of the supergroup CSNY--that he was no longer interested in them, he was going to follow his own path.  He didn't change his music all that much--at this point, it was still acoustic and electric guitars, country-western touches, the same vocal style--but the subject matter and outlook became much bleaker, and the rhythms and tunes far less engaging than the country-rock beats and singalong melodies of his earlier work.<br />Overall, I think this willfullness and defiance, this confessional indulgence, this &quot;you think you know me, well you dooooon't&quot; attitude has served Neil Young poorly.  Young is consistently better when he is in touch with his audience, as he clearly was on the early albums I mentioned, and on later classics like &quot;Rust Never Sleeps,&quot; &quot;Ragged Glory,&quot; &quot;Freedom&quot; and &quot;Harvest Moon&quot; he is breathtakingly insightful, powerful and still very much an individual despite the almost Springsteen-like common touch.<br />&quot;On the Beach&quot; is the grand exception that proves the rule.  It is a great album, and hearing it after all these years, it sounds much better than I remember it.  Yes, it's a downer, and on the surface it sounds listless at times.  But it is incredibly well-crafted, with some of the best lyrics he ever wrote.  Almost every song is great, and what used to be Side 2 (the title song, &quot;Motion Pictures&quot; and &quot;Ambulance Blues&quot;) is a startling trilogy that travels from utter despair, toward redemption and relief in love, and finally ending in mature reflection as he puts his entire life on the line and in the lyrics of the closing song.<br />Several of the songs have the word &quot;blues&quot; in the title, and believe it, there is more traditionally structured blues on this record than any other Neil Young did, and he makes great use of the form.  I guess what makes this record work for me is the way he uses his own personal disasters, the deaths of his friends, as a metaphor for the disastrous end of an era, one that starts so optimistically in the &quot;old folkie days (when) the air was magic&quot; but ends with this image: &quot;All along the Navajo trail/burn-outs stub their toes on garbage pails.&quot;  Hippie wreckage is everywhere on this album, and the deaths of his friends are finally understood as the betrayal of dreams for which not enough people took responsibility.&quot; in the title, and believe it, there is more traditionally structured blues on this record than any other Neil Young did, and he makes great use of the form.  I guess what makes this record work for me is the way he uses his own personal disasters, the deaths of his friends, as a metaphor for the disastrous end of an era, one that starts so optimistically in the &quot;old folkie days (when) the air was magic&quot; but ends with this image: &quot;All along the Navajo trail/burn-outs stub their toes on garbage pails.&quot;  Hippie wreckage is everywhere on this album, and the deaths of his friends are finally understood as the betrayal of dreams for which not enough people took responsibility.

B00000GBHA|5.0|When I moved to Detroit's Cass Corridor neighborhood in 1991, and for the ensuing decade, Rodriguez was just a guy I would run into on the street or at the liquor store, or have a drink with.  We actually met because people thought it was funny to see two guys in the same neighborhood walking around in biker boots and black sport coats when it was 90 degrees...  I knew he was a musician (the first time I saw him play was when my band's guitar tech's band opened up for him at a bar down the street), but so am I, and so were half the people who lived there...  When he was \\"rediscovered\\" a couple of years ago, we were all amazed that his music had been so successful (I think he was too!).  Most of us who gigged in and around Detroit played only for the love of music, because before Eminem & the White Stripes, most of us didn't have a hope in hell of getting beyond independent releases and regional tours...  Anyway, Rodriguez is a great guy and an incredible singer/songwriter, and it's wonderful that he's finally getting his due.  The amount of musical talent in this city will never cease to amaze me...  Of course, When you've seen a former Motown superstar singing on the streetcorner (John R & Adelaide) for a ten dollar rock, the fact that the guy down the street is a major international star isn't quite so surprising...!    Dimestore Liam  Detroit

B00008EY9G|5.0|I think there are two basic types of movie watchers.  The first goes into each film trying to figure it out.  That's the whole goal.  If they succeed, then the movie is \\"predictable\\" and \\"stupid\\".  If not, then the \\"plot made no sense\\" or \\"whole thing was just so boring\\" and other comments.  No way to win.<br />The second type of movie watcher sees the film to enjoy the movie and does not make guessing the twists or the endings the whole goal.  This is me.  Because of this, I was truly able to enjoy \\"Identity\\", especially when the story took its turn.  <br />You see, anyone remotely familiar with great stories in the last hundred years has heard of Agatha Christie's \\"And Then There Were None\\" where one by one people die at the hand of some unknown killer on site, since leaving the scene is impossible.  The killer must be one of them.  For the first hour, this appears to be a retread of this classic tale.<br />At this point in the movie, either you are in category 1 and you hate the film, or you are in category 2 and you love it because it will challenge you and it will hit you hard.  Even if you are able to see the surprise coming, you have to admit that looking through the story it does not cheat.  It stays faithful to the parameters it has set and that's all you can ask.<br />Yes, the acting is good and the screenplay is well executed and editing and all that, but this film does not depend on the actors.  It works well as fiction and I think you could have replaced the actors with other capable performers and not lost much.  Very few people I have spoken with have been real concerned with Cusack's or Liotta's performances.<br />I will admit that the very end seems a little tacked on.  Hollywood seems to have a formula they have to follow and one is an ending like this one.  It works, but it is unnecessary.  The movie actually twists twice and it does not have to.  <br />Just look at the comments throughout these reviews.  Most are either love or hate.  I think some people get mad when movies put one over on them... not me!  I'll be first in line to get the DVD when it comes out.  This is simply one of the most effective horror movies I have ever seen.  It's Hitchcock meets Christie meets Steven King.  I hope you enjoy it.

B000002AGM|5.0|What in god's name more is there to say about this recording to someone who has not listened to it, and listened to it all the way through? I think I've listened to it more than any other CD I own. Miles on the flugelhorn is perfect. Gil Evans' arrangements are perfect. The choice of tunes--from Dave Brubeck's &quot;The Duke&quot; to Ahmad Jamal's &quot;New Rhumba&quot; to Evans' indescribably beautiful &quot;Blues for Pablo&quot;--are all perfect.
